The DA has worked with many partners
- Lullabot on initial designs
 - Zyxware on the contrib module prototype and initial implementation
 - And now QED42 to help finalize the module for inclusion in 9.3 - and backport to Drupal 7

text:
I have added bookmarks to the top of this channel with links to:
• the issue for inclusion in core
• the contrib module
• and the <http://drupal.org|drupal.org> issue for the <http://drupal.org|drupal.org> feed.
author: U06NAEYSF

text:
*Next steps* (taken from the core inclusion issue):
• QED42 team to install locally and do code review/discovery - find questions
• Finalize the feed from <http://Drupal.org|Drupal.org>
• Complete tests: <https://www.drupal.org/project/announce/issues/3198730|#3198730: Automated tests for Announce>
• Standardize language to ‘announcements’ rather than ‘alerts’
• Open the merge request on this issue
• [[D7 Backport can start from here]]
• Usability review
• Accessibility review
• Product manager review - Finalize policy for how the feed is to be used
• Framework manager review
• Release manager review - determine if we need to start as experimental, or can skip experimental since it is not a site-feature

text:

Feel free to respond in threads.
author: U2T8M7PA4

text:
:one: *Design discussion:*
- What type of styling we should adopt.
Current style is as per the “Claro” theme. So should we theme it according to Claro or Seven?
author: U2T8M7PA4

text:
:two: *Dedicated “/announcement” url:*
- Currently there is dedicated url for announcement as well.
Do we need to keep a dedicated page for announcements?
- We might need to theme the individual page then.
author: U2T8M7PA4

text:
:three: *Proposal to use cron based approach:*
Leverage hook_cron to periodically refresh the data.
Currently it is happening when we click on
“Announcement” icon. Upon clicking, first we are checking in temp storage and send API request if temp storage is empty.

Do we need some sort of cron features like `update` module which periodically sends requests and updates the data in background?
author: U2T8M7PA4

text:
:four: *Notification Read/un-read feature:*
Design has the feature for marking message as read/un-read.
Do we need to consider in scope for this iteration?
author: U2T8M7PA4

text:
:five: API Endpoints:
Does API endpoints have filter facility to request with version arguments etc?
For ex:
If we want to fetch notifications related to Drupal 7, we can send requests like <https://api.drupal.org/announcements.json?version=7> etc?
That way we can have lesser response data to process on module’s end.

We can also reduce response size by adding timestamp.
i.e. if we want to fetch all the notifications published after last read notification. We can send last read timestamp and fetch specific notifications only.
author: U2T8M7PA4

text:
:six: API response data freshness:
Currently data is stored in tempstore for 4 hours (14400 seconds).
Is it fine or we want more real time data?
author: U2T8M7PA4

text: <@U4PT7ES0M> <@U6V3XQXMF> ^^
author: U2T8M7PA4

text: We had a conversation about this a while back and decide, let's not render the full page articles directly in the Drupal UI - let's just render the teasers and let people click out to d.o for the full message.

author: U06NAEYSF

text:
I think submitting with Claro theming is *correct* as the target because Claro will be the new default.

I think we should see what it looks like if a user renders it using the Seven theme and do our best to make sure it is still functional (doesn't have to be pretty)

text:

I *thought* there was something in the codebase for this already maybe?
author: U06NAEYSF

author: U06NAEYSF

text: Not sure - and maybe that code didn't actually get written - but I'd look more closely to see if we already did something like that and if not, either add a cron that defaults to checking every 3 or 6 hours maybe (doesn't need to be heavy - there will almost never be more than 1 announcement a day) - or find someway to trigger it by 'first visit to the admin page in a session' so it happens 'just in time' for the user, but isn't constant polling for updates.

text: (The code was supposed to be a user context object which remembers read state by user)
author: U06NAEYSF

text: We haven't built that functionality into <http://Drupal.org|Drupal.org> - but that might be a good idea - would need <@U3U1SD32R> to think through how he wants that to work.
author: U06NAEYSF

text: Our original thought was version as another field, and re-using core's existing semver parsing function to figure the version
author: U06NAEYSF

text: But open to other approaches.
author: U06NAEYSF

text: I think this is *probably* fine because these announcements are never *urgent* data...
author: U06NAEYSF

text: <@UJHK24PT3> If you happen to know answers to some of these questions it would be a great help if you could chime in as well ^^
author: U06NAEYSF

text: I’d prefer serving everything with the version metadata as another field. That might be a bit more data, but is more-readily cacheable. And a `?version=7` parameter makes less sense nowadays, with semver, things can affect an arbitrary range of versions, so we would end up with `?version=7.80` or `?version=9.2.4` and we have to do every comparison server-side anyway.
author: U3U1SD32R

text: And needs to be functional with anything someone sets as their admin theme.
author: U3U1SD32R

text: The feed should have exactly what we want to provide then, we do the truncation server-side, and no client-side trimming.
author: U3U1SD32R

text: In some cases, I expect we might change the announcement after it is published for corrections/clarifications, so we’ll want it fetching all announcements, regardless of publish date.
author: U3U1SD32R

text: Maybe less real-time. If there’s some issue contacting <http://Drupal.org|Drupal.org> for more than 4 hours, having them cached for maybe 24h makes sense to me. And refresh maybe 1 - 4 times a day via cron, assuming cron is set up.
author: U3U1SD32R

text: I suppose we can’t control when people run cron, but it would be nice to have requests come at arbitrary times. Our CDN can/does absorb a flood of requests at the top of the hour, but it would be nice to have requests be made more-evenly. And yes, I’d expect this to work like update module - fetching on cron with some UI fallback since many sites don’t have cron set up.
author: U3U1SD32R

text:
The items I am aware from reading back through seem to be:
• icon should support forced color mode - and should be switched to svg anyway - mock in ckrina's comment in the issue
• the links should appear as blue underlined links in the *minimal* styling, and should match the style guide for seven and claro implementations
• The links *should not* be forced to target=blank_ for screen reader reasons
• The color contrast should be improved
• The 'sticky' posts should be clearly readable as sticky by screen readers as well, and not just rely on a background color change or other visual change
• We should consider making the 'learn more' link/button appear on every feed item, and distinguish sticky items some other way - a class for screen readers + a different background color, or some kind of 'pin' icon for sticky, or something else? 
Finally the only item that I'm not sure got a final answer:
• Do we want to use the off-canvas dialogue to have the announcement feed *pop over* the content *OR* open a sidebar drawer like it does now? (mimicking settings tray?)

text:
During last week's UX call, we discussed what would be the best place to visually display messages and communications with users (project announce).
One of the ideas, inspired by Wordpress, was bringing back "Dashboard" to Drupal.
I am watching now the awesome DrupalCon Europe session about `Gin admin theme`, where <@U3A2ZDSE4> presented the idea of... a dashboard! :slightly_smiling_face:
Great timing!
author: U47JYK2DT

text: I was thinking that as well, with the current move to implement things like content editor role and other editor focused things; I think the time is right for Drupal to revisit the idea of a Dashboard.
author: U6XHB78BV

text: To be clear, a Dashboard that's actually useful, not some fluffy nonsense that people just ignore, and has a lot of dependencies that no one wants to maintain.
author: U6XHB78BV

text: Could we have a persona-based Dashboards: Admin dashboard, Content Manager dashboard, Content Editor dashboard; These would be slightly different depending on the persona: admin dashboard would be surface important things from status report, whereas content editor dashboard would be a mini version of `admin/content` (maybe this is how we finally do <https://www.drupal.org/project/drupal/issues/2377543>).
author: U6XHB78BV

text: However, they could all contain common elements, such as the Messaging/Announcements system that this very channel is focused on. Perhaps a two column layout, where the left column is persona based, and the right column is common across all personas.
author: U6XHB78BV

text: Maybe it could be worked in with this issue <https://www.drupal.org/project/ideas/issues/3203618> which is essentially advocating for a persona based toolbar.
author: U6XHB78BV

text: We should look up what the original dashboard supported.
author: U1A7P6GTZ

text: Perhaps, a persona based dashboard, would make it easier for us to do <https://www.drupal.org/project/drupal/issues/2862859>
author: U6XHB78BV

text: That said with layout builder this could possibly be mostly configuration now.
author: U1A7P6GTZ

text:
> That said with layout builder this could possibly be mostly configuration now.
Definitely! We have way better tools in Core now to make this work in a sustainable way, compared to the D6/7 days.

text: Here is screenshots and docs about how it works in Drupal 7 to this day ;) <https://www.drupal.org/docs/7/core/modules/dashboard/working-with-the-dashboard|https://www.drupal.org/docs/7/core/modules/dashboard/working-with-the-dashboard>

text:
The biggest struggle with Dashboard and why it ultimately failed in round 1 was less about the architecture (agreed that LB would make this easy today) and more that there was no follow-through on creating useful, meaningful metrics to display in such a dashboard (esp. thinking through on a per-role basis... what is useful to admins and what is useful to content authors and what is useful to end users are often 12 different things ;)). We ended up with a "one size fits all" approach with a bunch of views in that were easy to create, but not very useful day-to-day.

So if we're going to bring it back, it needs some actual design/thought behind what blocks it needs to show, and to whom, and we need some folks stepping up to make those "inner parts" come to reality, even if that means adding some extra features here and there (e.g. the ability to show views as charts, as an example).

And _definitely_ agreed it's a whole other initiative and shouldn't block this one in any way. :slightly_smiling_face:

Definitely worth an ideas issue though! And some historical research into the older incarnation, which AFAIK had some aspirational designs as part of it.
author: U1AA5D42H

text:
Agree with everything there that <@U06NAEYSF> and <@U1AA5D42H> have said.
> (esp. thinking through on a per-role basis... what is useful to admins and what is useful to content authors and what is useful to end users are often 12 different things ;))
Absolutely agree here, that was part of my thinking when I was talking about a persona based approach, if nothing else it forces us to think about what's useful for those different types of users, which as you say are very different

author: U1ET7192M

text: Okay! So we'll see what <@U06HDFAP5> and <@U49HYCETX> have to say about those button styles and any thing that would be *brand new* to Claro for this feature - and either a) try to replace them with an existing pattern or b) move the styles for Claro for the project messaging feature out of this issue and into a follow up.
author: U06NAEYSF

text: exactly :slightly_smiling_face:
author: U1ET7192M

text:
My take is it's reasonable to move the Claro part into a followup provided the current buttons don't introduce any accessibility issues, so check for stuff like:
• The buttons have visually distinct hover and focus states
• All of those states meet AA contrast requirements
• They're keyboard navigable
My rationale for this: while it's not acceptable to introduce accessibility bugs, I'm fine adding a little bit of tech debt to an _experimenta_l theme as long as it's added to the roadmap to Claro being Stable There are plenty of other parts of Claro that are acutely unfinished and look less than perfect. I can appreciate those who might be reluctant to knowingly add tech debt, but I feel adding a little bit of manageable debt to an unfinished + experimental theme is a fine tradeoff for maintaining momentum on a great new feature with healthy community enthusiasm behind it.

coming back late to the party, according to <https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/revert>

>  If used by a site's own styles (the author origin), revert rolls back the property's cascaded value to the user's custom style, if one exists; otherwise, it rolls the style back to the user agent's default style.

author: U6K08UK96

text:
*Trigger the notifications as new*:
`ddev drush php:eval "\Drupal::service('user.data')->delete('announcements_feed');drupal_flush_all_caches();"`
author: U6K08UK96

text:
If you want to *test another feed URL*, for example the one on the tests, you need to override the feed_url:
• Copy `sites/example.settings.local.php` to `sites/default/settings.local.php`
• Uncomment the last three lines of `sites/default/settings.php` to include the above file
• Edit the `sites/development.services.yml` and add `announcements_feed.feed_url: <https://drupal.ddev.site/core/modules/announcements_feed/tests/announce_feed/community-feeds.json>` to the `parameters` section (replace `<http://drupal.ddev.site|drupal.ddev.site>` with the URL of the testing environment)
• `ddev drush php:eval "\Drupal::service('user.data')->delete('announcements_feed');\Drupal::service('keyvalue.expirable')->get('announcements_feed')->deleteAll();drupal_flush_all_caches();"`

text:
Not sure if it’s an intended side effect, but any organisation could have their own custom feed that, as long as it follows the format of <https://www.drupal.org/announcements.json|this one>, could be set to their sites (or the sites they build).

ie: a government or university might want to create a feed and have all their sites read from that feed instead of the d.o one. It’d be a one line change in the services file to overwrite `announcements_feed.feed_url`.
